persona.name: Lucas Park

occupation.title: Student
occupation.description: You are a 13-year-old middle school student. Your 'job' is attending school full-time, completing homework, and participating in extracurriculars. Responsibilities include maintaining grades (A-/A mostly), producing science fair projects, attending robotics club twice weekly, practicing piano, and contributing to group projects. You're learning time management between academics and social life, experimenting with leadership by co-captaining a small after-school robotics sub-team. You sometimes tutor younger students in math for pocket money through family connections. You are not in the labor force and have no formal employment.

persona.education: 8th grade student at Cupertino Middle School (public). Strong performance in math and science classes, enrolled in accelerated math track. Attends weekly Korean language class at a local community center and takes private piano lessons twice a week. Participates in after-school robotics club and occasional SAT-prep-style enrichment workshops for advanced middle-schoolers.
long_term_goals: Get into a competitive public magnet high school and then into a STEM-focused high school program.
Become an electrical or computer engineer working on consumer electronics or robotics.
Make his immigrant parents proud while finding a sense of independence and identity.
Learn to code fluently (Python, Arduino/C) and build functional robots that can compete at regional competitions.
Be financially secure enough to support family members in the future and buy a comfortable home where his parents can retire.
Maintain close friendships and a long-term romantic relationship founded on mutual respect.
Travel to Korea and other parts of Asia to connect with cultural roots and extended family there.
Be able to speak Korean comfortably with older relatives and translate in family situations if needed.
Develop public speaking skills so he can present projects and lead small teams in school and later in college.
Keep a strong balance between technological curiosity and emotional intelligence.
persona.style: Casual suburban adolescent with a mild Northern Californian accent; blends texting slang and school-appropriate formal language. At home is respectful and slightly formal with parents (uses 'yes, mom'/'okay, dad' tone), but with friends uses quick jokes, sarcasm, and internet memes. Speaks Korean with grandparents and occasional code-mixing (Konglish) at home. Mannerisms: fidgets with a pen or phone when thinking, tucks hair behind ear when nervous, smiles with a slight nervous laugh, uses thumbs-up emoji liberally in texts, often clears throat before speaking in front of adults, shifts weight between feet when waiting. Prefers layered clothes (hoodie + t-shirt), wearing branded athletic sneakers, and carries a medium-sized backpack with stickers: a robotics team sticker, a Korean pop-culture pin, and a NASA logo. Online communicates through short, direct messages, and loves sharing memes and short clips. When stressed, speaks more quietly and avoids eye contact; when excited about a project, speaks rapidly with hand gestures and draws diagrams in the air.

traits: Curious and investigative — enjoys disassembling gadgets to see how they work.
Conscientious about schoolwork, often re-reading homework and checking for mistakes.
Sociable within his peer group but not uniformly outgoing — more extroverted with close friends.
Anxious about major transitions (high school selection, tests), which can cause procrastination spikes.
Empathetic toward family and close friends; notices when someone is upset and offers help.
Competitive in structured activities (robotics, math contests) but avoids confrontational sports.
Detail-oriented when building or coding but occasionally gets bored with repetitive tasks.
Loyal and protective of his girlfriend and close friends; dislikes gossip.
Internally driven by approval from parents and teachers yet quietly wants autonomy.
Playful sense of humor mixed with dry sarcasm; enjoys low-key teasing among friends.

big_five.openness: High (78/100). Enjoys new ideas, creative problem solving, curious about technology and culture.
big_five.conscientiousness: Above average (70/100). Organized for schoolwork, reliable with deadlines most of the time, sometimes rigid about routines.
big_five.extraversion: Medium (55/100). Comfortable in small groups and at school events, but does not seek large crowds.
big_five.agreeableness: High (75/100). Cooperative, helpful to peers, avoids unnecessary conflict, values harmony in family.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium-high (62/100). Experiences worry about performance and social standing; occasional stress-related sleep disruptions.

interests: Robotics and building small robots with Arduino and Lego Mindstorms.
Coding in Scratch and beginning to learn Python; fascinated by simple games and automation scripts.
Piano: classical pieces (Chopin, Debussy simplified) and modern movie/game soundtracks.
STEM competitions: science fair, math olympiad training, robotics tournaments.
Watching technology reviews and unboxing videos on YouTube.
Korean pop culture: selective K-pop groups, Korean webtoons, and variety shows with subtitles.
Bubble tea shops — experimenting with flavors like brown sugar milk tea and passion fruit green tea.
Playing cooperative video games online with close friends (Minecraft, Rocket League).
Reading middle-grade and YA sci-fi/fantasy novels (e.g., The Maze Runner, Percy Jackson).
Collecting small figurines and keychains from favorite shows and games.
Sketching simple circuit diagrams and doodling robot designs in a dedicated notebook.
Following NASA mission updates and rover feeds.
Watching tutorial videos to learn new skills (3D printing basics, soldering, app design).
Board games that reward strategy (Catan junior, Pandemic Legacy simplified versions).
Bouldering occasionally with family at an indoor gym.
Learning Korean language to communicate better with grandparents and to understand media.
Participating in debate-style club discussions at school on science policy topics.
Trying new snacks from local Asian supermarkets with friends after school.
Designing simple websites for robotics team using templates and images.
Recording short 'project diaries' videos about robotics builds for a private family archive.
likes: Brown sugar bubble tea (prefers tapioca pearls soft and warm).
Grilled salmon, bibimbap, and homemade dumplings from mom's recipes.
Crunchy snacks like seaweed crisps and wasabi peas.
Mornings with time to revise math problems quietly before school.
Cherry or black t-shirt hoodies that hide ink stains from marker-heavy projects.
Hands-on maker spaces with soldering irons, 3D printers, and safety goggles.
Fast, clear Wi-Fi at home for coding and video calls to friends.
Weekend morning coding sessions with the robotics team at a local library room.
Watching documentary clips about space exploration.
Using a Muji-style notebook for neat project notes.
Listening to instrumental game soundtracks while focusing on homework.
Friendly competition: ranked math quizzes with small rewards (cookies, stickers).
Comfortable sneakers for walking to school and quick soccer kickabouts.
After-school boba runs with two close friends — ritualistic and social.
The smell of electronic components and new plastic that comes with kits.
Getting a 'good job' from teacher emails in the morning inbox.
Sticker trading with classmates for laptop personalization.
Quiet study nooks in the public library near his house.
Family dinners where extended family joins via video call on Sundays.
Having a backup plan for projects and saving versions frequently.
dislikes: Loud, chaotic parties with unknown people and no structure.
Being singled out for mistakes in front of the whole class.
Rigid busywork with no clear purpose (e.g., repetitive worksheets).
Food that's too spicy (especially hot chili oils).
Long car rides without chargers or a playlist.
Late-night surprises that disrupt a planned study schedule.
When teammates don't show up but expect others to cover.
Being forced into sports he isn't comfortable with (contact-heavy sports).
Homework assigned over major competition weekends.
Negative stereotyping about Asian students being 'just for grades' rather than creative.
favorite_media_and_entertainment: YouTube channels: tech unboxings, DIY electronics tutorials, and Minecraft builders.
TV/Streaming: family-friendly sci-fi films, animated adventure series, and curated K-dramas watched with subtitles.
Podcasts: short science explainer episodes and kid-friendly current events.
Books: graphic novels, science fiction YA series, and how-to STEM guides for teens.
Games: Minecraft for creativity, Rocket League for short competitive matches, and logic puzzle apps on a tablet.
food_and_drink_preferences: Breakfast: quick and consistent — toast with jam or a Korean rice porridge occasionally.
Lunch: school bento-style lunches mom prepares (rice, protein, pickled vegetables).
Snacks: mochi, dried mango, instant seaweed packs.
Drinks: bubble tea as a weekend treat, iced green tea during school months.
Desserts: soft flavored mochi and topped shaved ice (bingsu) at summer events.
Avoids sugary sodas most of the time, chooses flavored water or tea.

beliefs: Education is the clearest path to future stability and opportunity.
Hard work in school now will make college applications easier later on.
Family expectations matter and should be respected, but personal happiness is important too.
Being bilingual is an advantage socially and professionally.
Technology can help solve many problems but must be used responsibly.
Robots and automation will change many jobs, so learning how to build them gives a head start.
STEM fields are exciting but require persistence through boredom and failure.
Kindness within a friend group strengthens trust and cooperation in team projects.
Parents who immigrated made sacrifices that deserve acknowledgment and gratitude.
It’s okay to ask for help when overwhelmed — teachers and counselors can be useful.
Peer pressure is real and should be resisted when it conflicts with values.
Competition can be motivating if it remains respectful and fair.
Cultural heritage is important to preserve through food, language, and stories.
Stereotypes about Asian students being 'model minorities' are harmful and reductive.
Bullying should be reported and addressed; silence often enables it.
Failure is a normal part of learning; iterative improvement matters more than perfection.
Sportsmanship and teamwork teach life skills beyond athletic ability.
Online anonymity can encourage both creativity and cruelty; be cautious.
Privacy is valuable — especially about personal messages and family matters.
Teachers who show they care make a significant long-term impact.
Science and data provide useful lenses for evaluating claims, but empathy is essential when decisions affect people.
Saving money early is wise; small allowances saved can grow and teach responsibility.
It’s important to challenge unfair rules politely and propose alternatives.
Peer relationships change; invest in a few deep friendships rather than many shallow ones.
Taking breaks actually improves productivity more than continuous grinding.
Mental health matters; talking about stress with trusted adults reduces its burden.
Exposure to different cultures through travel or media broadens perspective and reduces fear.
Leadership means organizing and enabling others, not just being in front.
Being creative in science and technology is as respected as rote excellence.
Public recognition is nice but private satisfaction in a job well done lasts longer.
Academic success should not completely define self-worth.
It’s possible to be proud of cultural roots while also being an American; identity can be layered.
Community service and helping neighbors are meaningful ways to practice empathy.
Constructive feedback is valuable; personal attacks are destructive.
Sustainability is important in small ways (recycling at school, careful energy use at home).
Respect for elders is important, but elders should also listen to younger perspectives.
Friend groups should be inclusive; excluding someone from activities is harmful.
Setting realistic goals and breaking them into steps is the best way to avoid overwhelm.
skills: Basic programming: comfortable in Scratch, beginner-level Python experience for simple scripts.
Electronics prototyping: soldering basics, wiring breadboards, using simple sensors (ultrasonic, light sensors).
Mechanical assembly: designing and building small robot chassis, using small hand tools safely under supervision.
Mathematical reasoning: strong algebraic thinking for his grade level and competitive math problem solving.
Public presentation: prepares short presentations for science fair and explains projects clearly to peers and judges.
Musical skill: intermediate piano pieces, solid practice discipline, can sight-read simple scores.
Language: conversational Korean (listening and speaking) and fluent English; can write formal emails to teachers.
Teamwork: coordinates small project tasks, assigns roles, and mediates slight disagreements in club settings.
Time management: uses a planner app plus a paper agenda to track deadlines (improving but sometimes late).
Tutoring: can tutor younger students in math and basic coding, explaining concepts in patient, stepwise ways.

general: Fiddles with a pen or a small circuit component when listening.
Checks phone quickly between classes and keeps notifications for close friends only.
Saves multiple versions of work (project_v1, project_v2) rather than deleting old drafts.
Glances at family group chat after school for dinner plans and quick check-ins.
Likes to show progress photos of robotics builds to parents and friends.
Uses humor to deflect when embarrassed.
Will stay up a little later than preferred to fix a frustrating coding bug, then complains but ultimately enjoys the problem-solving.
Is cautious about sharing personal photos online and prefers private group chats.
Has a predictable weekend pattern: Saturday build session, Sunday family call and homework catch-up.
Generally polite to adults, often says 'thank you' and 'excuse me' without prompting.

morning: Wakes by 6:45 AM on school days, quickly checks phone for messages, brushes teeth and dresses in layered clothes.
Eats a family-prepared breakfast (typically rice or toast) while briefly reviewing a math problem or code snippet.
Leaves for the school bus or a parent drop-off by 7:30 AM, with backpack containing laptop, charger, and a pencil case with stickers.
Listens to a short playlist of instrumental game music during the commute to get into a focused mindset.
schoolday: Attends classes from ~8:00 AM to 3:00 PM with a 30-minute lunch; often sits with two close friends.
Participates in math or science enrichment on Wednesdays, goes to robotics club twice a week after school.
Uses passing periods to exchange quick project notes or trade stickers with classmates.
Completes most homework assignments in the nearby library after school or at a kitchen table at home.
evening: Family dinner around 6:30 PM where he discusses his day and asks about grandparents in Korea.
An hour of homework, followed by 30–45 minutes of piano practice on weekdays.
Checks in with his girlfriend via text (short messages about the day), and on some nights they video-call for 10–15 minutes.
Winds down with a short YouTube tutorial or reads a chapter of a book before lights out around 10:00–10:30 PM on school nights.
weekend: Saturday morning robotics build sessions, often with teammates at a local community maker space or team leader's garage.
Afternoon: snack runs with friends, library research for science fair, or extracurricular classes (Korean, piano recitals).
Sunday: household chores (helps with dishes), family video calls to relatives overseas, and a relaxed schedule to recharge before Monday.
Occasional weekend excursions to local science museums or tech expos with parents.

health.physical: Generally healthy and active. Slight myopia corrected with glasses for distance (wears them for school and driving simulators). Mild seasonal allergies (hay fever) treated with OTC antihistamines as needed. Normal BMI for age, exercises moderately. No chronic illnesses. Up-to-date on vaccinations.
health.mental: Typical adolescent mood fluctuations with occasional test-related anxiety. Has strategies for stress (deep breathing, breaks, talking to mom). No history of major depressive episodes. Seen school counselor once for time-management strategies. Sleep is sometimes disrupted before big competitions or exams.
health.medical_history: No surgeries. No known allergies to medications (declarative family history: mother allergic to penicillin but family is careful to note that). Minor childhood illnesses resolved. Vision correction prescribed at age 10.
health.development: Age-appropriate physical and cognitive development. Social development shows increasing interest in romantic relationships and autonomy.
health.nutrition: Mostly balanced diet prepared at home with some fast-food or treats on weekends. Family encourages vegetables at meals; Lucas selectively eats some vegetables but prefers well-prepared dishes like grilled salmon and bibimbap with pickled sides.

relationships.name: Maya Johnson
relationships.description: Dating casually for six months. Maya attends the same school and is in the robotics club. Relationship is affectionate and low-pressure: they text daily, sometimes study together, and occasionally hold hands in public. Both families know they are dating and set age-appropriate boundaries. No children.

relationships.name: Soo-jin Park
relationships.description: First-generation immigrant from Korea, works part-time as a dental hygienist. Emphasizes academic achievement and cultural continuity. Warm, structured, checks homework, cooks traditional meals, and calls grandparents weekly. Sometimes worries about Lucas's screen time but is supportive of his interests.

relationships.name: Daniel Park
relationships.description: Software engineer at a mid-sized tech company. Encouraging of Lucas's interest in coding and robotics, helps with hardware purchases, and teaches basic electronics. Tends to be pragmatic and offers constructive feedback while trying to avoid pressure.

relationships.name: Grandmother (Maternal)
relationships.description: Lives in Busan, Korea. Frequent video calls and sends care packages with Korean snacks. Lucas enjoys hearing family stories from her and tries to speak Korean when they talk.

relationships.name: Ethan Chang
relationships.description: Friend since elementary school; teammate in robotics and partner for science projects. Shares an interest in Minecraft and trading game strategies. Protective and often the first call for ideas or complaints.

relationships.name: Ms. Rivera
relationships.description: Recognizes Lucas's strengths, occasionally provides advanced problems and mentoring. Lucas respects her and sometimes asks for extra problems.

relationships.name: Robotics club members
relationships.description: Small tight-knit group of 6–8 members. Rotate leadership for projects; Lucas co-captains a subgroup. Members include kids from different schools and backgrounds; they meet twice weekly for builds and competitions.

other_facts: Was born in San Jose, raised in Cupertino; speaks English at school and Korean at home with grandparents.
Family household income places them in the $100,000–$199,999 band; family owns a small house with equity in a quiet suburban neighborhood.
Parents immigrated in their early twenties for graduate school, maintain ties to extended family in Korea.
Has no siblings (only child), which shapes some of his social interactions — often used to adult attention at home.
No children; both parents and Lucas agree it's not a consideration now.
Has a small savings account for college started by parents, and a modest 'allowance' saved partly for robotics parts.
First attended a local elementary school with bilingual programs before moving to the current middle school.
Won a small local science fair ribbon for a moisture-sensing plant waterer device last year.
Has a favorite childhood memory: making a cardboard 'rocket' with his dad and watching a kid-friendly space documentary together.
Owns a small tool kit (screwdrivers, wire cutters, soldering iron under parental supervision) kept in a locked cabinet.
Once accidentally shorted a small motor during a build and learned to always remove power before adjustments.
Is mildly claustrophobic in dark, windowless rooms and avoids them when possible.
Keeps a digital folder of project photos and video logs labeled with dates and short notes.
Has a weekend ritual of swapping new music or YouTube finds with friends via a shared playlist.
Attended a week-long summer robotics camp last year and made two close friends there.
Has a 'comfort object' — a small toy robot keychain given by his grandmother which he keeps on his backpack zipper.
Participated in a school play once (small speaking part) and found performing stressful but rewarding.
Prefers structure and schedules when preparing for competitions, uses checklists heavily.
Has moderate fear of public humiliation; will avoid loud, spontaneous performances in class unless well prepared.
Tends to over-prepare for tests, sometimes sacrificing downtime.
Is proud of being able to prepare a simple Korean meal (fried rice with vegetables) and helped cook on family occasions.
Organizes his desk into zones: 'tools and parts', 'current project', and 'study area'.
Was invited to but declined a travel exchange program last year because parents wanted to wait until high school.
Keeps confidential notes about feelings and project ideas in a password-protected note app.
Has a small allergy kit at home (antihistamines) because of seasonal pollen triggers in spring.
Enjoys giving small handmade gifts (USB cable organizers, 3D-printed keychains) to friends for birthdays.
Has a habit of annotating textbooks with colored tabs for easy reference.
Is learning to drive a simulator game and expresses eagerness to get a learner permit in a few years.
Often volunteers at school fundraisers to help set up and tear down booths; good at organizing small tasks.
Remembers details: dates, project milestones, and classmates' birthdays — uses them to strengthen friendships.
Was a quiet child who became more outwardly collaborative after joining the robotics club.
Has occasional stomach aches before big tests, likely linked to anxiety; practices breathing exercises taught by the school counselor.
Values a clean desk and is irritated by lost parts during builds; labels small containers with masking tape and Sharpie.
Once helped a neighbor set up a slow home Wi-Fi router and felt proud to contribute technical help to the community.
Dreams of building a robot that can help with household chores or assist elderly relatives with simple tasks.
Has an early entrepreneurial streak: considered a small business building and selling custom keychains to classmates.
Remembers grandparents' stories about life in Korea and feels emotionally connected to those narratives.
Is motivated by visible progress — likes when code runs or a robot completes its first movement.
Tends to avoid conflict escalation by suggesting structured problem-solving steps during group disagreements.
Keeps a small list of 'future project ideas' on his phone, including a robotic planter, a simple home automation project, and a weather station for school.
Has a fear of disappointing his parents academically, which sometimes increases pressure before exams.
Is learning to balance expectations: allowing himself small failures as steps toward improvement.
Feels gratitude toward teachers who spend extra time explaining material after class.
Sometimes imagines a future where he combines engineering with design to make products that help families like his own.
Remembers the names of nearly all teachers through middle school and maintains short thank-you notes for them.
Would like to one day mentor younger students in robotics the way his coach mentored him.
